reviewText:
Well this is a weird game.

I'm not the type to play a bad game for a few minutes then quit and talk trash on it. I understand the work that could've gone into a title like this, albeit perhaps work aimed at squeezing every last penny out of a very, very young and impressionable audience. I like to get a good feel for every feature before I pass judgement.

And I must say, I have gotten quite a feel for this game.

The first problem here is that these developers are working with an IP that is very clearly targeted at a young audience. I know a lot of adults who go crazy over Toothless and I'm sure you do, too, but the game is designed in every corner to be aimed at really small kids. They'll get their parents to download it or they'll play in-browser, they'll see the shiny armor or dragons or they'll try to use the farm and lord knows that most kids aren't patient enough to wait 10 minutes for a plant to grow. So they'll get their parents to buy them gems and the money JumpStart wants is made. It's really damn grimy.

The second problem, ignoring the business model and focusing on gameplay, is that it is very buggy and prone to crashing. In the (at the time of writing) 9 hours I've spent playing, I have crashed while simply jumping around or walking about 6 times. I've frozen at a loading screen 3 times. And my menus have glitched and stayed onscreen with no way to close them about 4 times. That's just 3 kinds of bugs I've run into, and I'm sure only just 3 of many that OTHERS have had to put up with as well.

And as far as the questing goes. What the hell? It consists of walking back and forth between movie characters, getting shown a little movie clip sometimes, answering some trivia, and being told to go do the same minigames over and over. Of these minigames I've gotten to play so far, there's a target practice railshooter thing and a flying challenge. Initially you cannot use your dragon to play these, you need to use Toothless every hour for the railshooter, and you have to use another dragon for the flying challenges. For the flying nonsense, there's also a huge repetoire of dragons from the movies/show that you can use as well, but of course, only if you shell out the cash for the lovely microtransactions. And my favorite part of that is that every single one of them is 250 gems (about $2.00)..... except Toothless. He's 500! (about $5.00).

You can use your own dragon after you level it up and then age it. Teen years are good enough for the railshooter and glide challenges, and then adult is what you need for actual flying stuff. But all this takes Energy" from your dragon
date: which you can only replenish by either waiting or by feeding him fish you've caught in the fishing minigame thing. Well I mean
recommended: there's also microtransactions to help with the whole energy ordeal
hoursPlayed: but seeing as so far there've been microtransactions tied to almost every single facet of gameplay

reviewText:
How to get the most out of this game.

1. Create your viking using two or less options in every catagory!
2. Fly a dragon at 5 mph!
3. Click on some eggs which opens a window!
4. Get asked to pay 85 dollars for a membership!
5. Say no which will instantly crash the game!
6. Uninstall!

reviewText:
Plain and Simple:  Money Vacumm with Enough Bugs to start a career in Entomology.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I'm used to F2P MMO's that have Payment options but not to this level.
You pay for majority of the Items within this game; Some of the Dragons, or simple clothing items that provoke your interest towards the game are Member Exclusives or to expensive for the tiny amount of Gems the game gives you. If you make a mistake within your character you have to pay to delete it, Items that have appeal are Slapped down on a price that a F2P cannot get.
I played it twice and met advertisements around every corner, Even in the shop, needed to buy supplies to expand within the game such as Bait or Seeds for your farms, The gameplay is just something you Must experience to believe it,
-Crash Sim 2014: Dragon Edition.-
Oh I almost forgot, You have to be a member To name your character or Dragon, Else you Become VIKING_346IJ2418, Same with the Dragons.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I liked the movies, I read the books, I played the game, I left in a hurry, Never again.

reviewText:
I tried, i really did, i really wanted to like this game...I love the IP its based on.but this this is just crap. The graphics are, well to put it lightly, 10 years old. Its just not good enough for a modern game. The textures are just aweful. but this is not the worst part, i can live with bad graphics.

Lets start with account registration. You have an age choice, 5 options. Are you 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5? yep thats right. The game assumes that everyone playing it is under 6. through the registration process you rapidly discover a complete lack of tab change. so you cant just type in the answers into the fields you have to select the field first. This is just the start of the bad GUI design.

Apparently this game is a mobile phone port because the game puts huge buttons up on the screen for you to click on to accelerate and slow and also apparently fire fireballs, though that button was only flashed at me as a taunt, and accelerate consisted of going from standing still to a slight snails pace. After the rather basic flying tutorial you are required to then go choose a dragon. First it asks you a series of questions and recommends a dragon to you, then basically tells you to pick your own anyway and leaves you to try and work out what the eggs refer to. A more knowledgable person might know the IP enough to remember the names given to each of the dragons in the movie and what each looks like and does...i couldn't, went for one that looked good on the graphic next to the egg, and then got one that looked quite different to what i was expecting...

I then followed the arrows to 'flight school' where i promptly disconnected from the game for the 2nd time in 15 minutes and decided enough was enough.

I'd like to say the game has potential. but the truth is, with all the faults in the game, to fix it you probably pretty much need to scrap the engine and start from scratch, this time with an aim to be more graphically similar to the movies. They might be able to do something with it...but it would need a huge overhaul in the graphics just to make it look reasonable, and a big overhaul in the user interface.

reviewText:
I thought this was a cute and fun game. Kinda like a Facebook pay to win game though, but I have patience and refuse to pay for games, it ran decent-ish on my old computer, I loved the movie, just wanted to zone out... a lot of reasons to play it.

But this game blows so bad.

You can just glitch through the floor and fall forever. Then you can hop on your dragon and try to ride it back up and never get up there!

The camera controls are terrible, even if you zoom out and get to a position that is acceptable, it resets all the time whenever you do something, anything. Fly? Reset. Fireball? Reset. Zone through? Reset.

Speaking of controls, little to no volume controls - you can turn it on, or off. On is ear-blastingly, RIP headphones users loud. Off is... not even really off. Occasionally when you zone through or activate/turn in a quest, sound will come blasting out of nowhere and blow your eardrums out.

There's nothing really to do at all. It's all gathering quests, retrieval and delivery quests, and what appears to be a selection of daily quests (Hiccup will keep making you do his scientific theory BS over and over again and play the same movie scenes despite it having NOTHING TO DO WITH THE SUBJECT OR TASK AT HAND). There is absolutely no PvE. There appears to be some kind of PvP which is really just minigames vs each other.

Fishing sucks. It takes forever. You gotta buy, with real money (gems = real money) a better fishing pole so it doesn't suck.

Flying sucks. The only way for you to dismount is if you plow into the ground and hit the dismount button (or press R) but you cannot dismount in the air and there is practically no way to just LAND. LAND. LAND.

Speaking of plowing and dismounting, you can't use either of those words. So, the word for GETTING OFF OF YOUR DRAGON TO WALK AROUND, is censored.

Also for some reason this game censors what appears to be a selection of American first names. However, you can still make a character using those names - but if someone tries to call you by your name, nope, you are censored.


Oh my god why am I even writing a realistic review for this? Nobody cares and everyone already knows this game is crap.

EDIT ADDING TO THE LIST OF STUPIDLY BANNED WORDS:
plow
dismount
random American names
5, 10, five (you cannot even tell anyone what level things unlock and when your dragon levels up)
ANY FREAKING NUMBERS AT ALL omg mommy said I couldn't tell anyone how old I am on the internet or I'll get molested.

and my favorite, fart.

reviewText:
So here's my short opinion on School of Dragons.

I downloaded it with some friends because we were all curious about how a game based off this particular franchise would go. To be honest none of us really expected much. Upon downloading we were greeted by, if you have not already guessed from the other reviews, lots of loading screens. Loading screens aren't a bad thing...normally. But these are heavy and a bit sore on the eyes. The attempts to get you excited by all the new content fall flat when you cycle through the same 5 ads over and over for 10 minutes. They could be better designed but moving on.

The intro experience is a bit clunky but long story short you get to pick from a few dragon breeds and get your baby dragon. The colour customization is actually pretty solid and the dragon models are great for the level of graphics the game can handle. Excellent textures a fairly well contructed world and you're off to level up yourself and your baby dragon.

The game attempts to be educational and actually does a fairly decent job at being engaging about it...at first. You have some quests involving the scientific theory and although the game gets a bit 'please allow us to shove this information directly down your child's throat, you are very welcome' the sentiment does not go unnoted. You collect different minerals and see how they interact with dragonfire and check the results against your hypothesis. Actually kind of rad.

Too bad all the other science related quests are replaced with this Candy Crush Simulator that makes NO SENSE WHATSOVER. But I digress. I was fairly impressed at this point.

Then I tried to meet up with my friends.

After the initial dance of 'where are you' and 'meet me here' we finally made it to the same location. Only...my friends were not there. Ok, so there are different servers. No way to see which one you are on? No problem. We'll just exchange friend codes and teleport to each other. Only...you can only befriend someone on the same server as you.

Oh. Well then...challenge accepted. We spent the next hour switching from single player mode back to mmo mode until we found each other. Grand. Only there is a chance that when you leave the area you could swap servers. Graaaaaaand. No matter. We'll meet up later when our dragons can fly and explore together.

By the time our dragons could all fly, we had stumbled upon the most ridiculous series of bugs and paywalls imaginable.

Gems, in this game, just so happen to be truuuuuuly outrageous. They can be obtained for free, rarely and in small quantities. Otherwise you have to pay for them. That's fine, I don't need Gems right? Ho boy. You can't do anything without them.

Want another dragon? Gems. Saddle? Gems. Another go at a race? Gems. Open a chest you found? Gems. Start a clan? Gems.

Heck, some places you can't even get to without a membership. Not only that but if you don't have mum's credit card to get those sweet, outrageous beauties you can forget about playing at all. You're dragon can run out of energy. How do you fix that? Feeding them. How do you feed them? By fishing. Fishing bait costs gold which can be obtained through quests...which you need your dragon for. If your dragon is tired you can't do quests. Hazzah! I think you can recharge your dragon by paying gems though. So, yey.

Bugs include, quests that can only be completed by logging in on someone else's computer after attempting to light a campfire for two hours, quests that you never took, lead no where, and simply don't exist, and, my favorite, incomplete maps. INCOMPLETE MAPS.

There are literally places in this game where you can be flying over a mountain and suddenly it looks like the entire world is see through, like your minecraft server crashed or you're trying to play on your mum's flip phone again to prove you can. I was flying in the glitchy ocean (which should have a seziure warning on it btw because the shaders are bugged) and heading towards the island only to find a neat surprise. Its flat. Its literally a 2D render of the island the disappears when you pass go. I mean, come on. Don't make flying there an option if you're going to be lazy.

Half the trees are flat. There is a forest of 4 very sad, out of place trees in this one location that you have to go to for any quest involving chopping wood. MUST I GO ON?

And do you know what the worst part about this game is? It has freaking potential. It has such a good base but it feels like no one is working on it. I want to shut it down, give it to a team of college kids, and put it back up in a couple of months because it would probably be ACES and I would probably LOVE IT. Because flying on your own dragon is COOL and the setting is CHARMING but it all feels like an alpha game that someone ran out of energy for halfway through and still had to turn it in.

I hate this game and I want someone with some fire in their soul to take over the whole freaking project so I can sleep at night instead of sketching out ideas for a better system that does not wreek of being a quick cash grab. Ugh. Don't play it just go send some letters to the developers or find a kickstarter to fund. I don't know just don't download this until someone takes responsibility for this beautiful disaster.

reviewText:
School of Dragons: How to Train Your Dragon is a free to play, third person massive multiplayer online game based on the animated movie up the same name. There is a lot to do here, plenty of fetch quests and mini games that center around flying a dragon through checkpoints. Other than that, you can tend to your farm, planting crops, watering them and harvesting all in real time. There is even a button mashing fishing mini game to get fish to feed your dragon. The glaring issue that I have with flying through the rings are the controls. These controls are meant for a touch screen. You have a speed up, slow down and fire button all on your screen. There are now hot keys to assist those of us not using the entire screen as a keyboard.

The game makes great use of its movie license and has clips from the movie with the ability to skip them. Skip is good, but each clip gets followed by a question about what you just watched. The graphics in game are bright, bold and colorful, but I can't call them good or bad. Its somewhere between and they can't get adjusted. Its good for computers with lesser graphics cards. This is a game for kids given the license and the easy difficulty. Does that make it bad? By no means. Its still the controls without a touch screen that make it bad. There are a few voice overs and a few things are fully voiced, but for the most part its one line of voice with an entire paragraph in text. The music is good, but there's not much variety. The same songs loop over and over again. By the time I was done with a one minute race, I had heard the same loop a noticeable amount of times.

When you start the game, you create your character, male or female with a few frills. You can setup an account or play as a guest. Then you get dropped into the world after a lengthily update that could have been downloading as I was making my character. After that, you get to pilot the dragon Toothless from the movie through an easy course to get the hang of the controls. Then you get to hatch your own baby dragon after you answer a few questions. You get to color your dragon, but you can't chose the style or anything.

Since its a baby dragon, the game needs you to grow the dragon over time by participating in chores that I wouldn't call fun. You'll need to feed your dragon fish by doing the fishing mini game. First buy bait then it is just a simple button mashing or mouse clicking I should say. Easy stuff. Then if you want to keep your dragon happy and level up, you'll grow plants on your farm over real life time and be there to harvest them or they die. You'll spend gold on the seeds or just buy the plant itself from the guy standing next to your farm. It incorporates the addictive bring you back chore work of Farmville with the thrill of flying through rings like Superman 64! Feeding your dragon might be one of the joys a child gets from this game. Want to feed your dragon the crops you just grew? Well you can't do it in the farm even if the dragon is sitting right there. You need to exit the farm back into the main world to click on it to bring up a first person view that lets you feed and play with it. You are playing fetch with your own dragon! Having an enslaved beast bring you back a ball for your amusement might be fun to apartment dwellers who are allergic to reptiles. Not just that, but you can shine a torch light like a laser pointer that gets your dragon to chase after it.

When its time to play the game and not just do chores in it, you'll visit the flight club where you get an adult dragon to pilot. Just fly through the checkpoints or touch flags and then make it to the end. That's it. I feel like there is an issue with hit detection, like I couldn't touch a flag around a rock wall between my dragon and the flag and it still counted. I guess that is a testament of how easy the game is. If you miss a checkpoint or a flag, it doesn't matter that much, because you get a grade for each course. Getting a B+ or higher grade unlocks the next course in the circuit. You can't just go to the next course, you need to get out, then select the next course. It seems like wasted time. Not just that, but there is only one circuit unlocked for free players. Then you get to use new abilities like fire to blast down targets that lock on instantly so you can't miss.  Some dragons have special powers that let you charge your fireball to destroy obstacles. When you complete each course, you are given gold to buy things. You will need to buy gems to unlock the rest.

With this being a free to play game, it has micro transactions. They are everywhere. Premium items. Premium circuits to fly in. Don't want to wait to grow your dragon or wait for a plant to mature? You bet that you can pay gems to have it done instantly. You spend real world money to get gems. Not just that, but there is a membership system for $10 a month up to $85 for 12 months. Members get in game discounts and the game tells you. 10 gold for seeds, but the membership price is 8 gold. You're missing out on 2 gold savings. You can also get gems by inviting your friends and having them register. Do it. Invite them. Make them register. Get the gems. Use the gems. Just invite your friends. Get them hooked. Do it.

Since this is a MMO, there are updates in game. These updates feel longer than they need to be. Sometimes it tells me that my Internet lost connection, but it didn't. This left me stuck in a loading screen. After five minutes, I had to Alt + F4 to exit the game, because there was no sort of menu during the loading screen to get out of it. The game has also crashed a few times for random reasons. Crashed in game and then during a movie clip. Then your instructor gives you a one question quiz about what you had just seen. Even though I was wrong, the game let it slide.

It plays like other third person MMOs, you run from person to person that gives you a quest. There is no death or combat. What I didn't like is I'd be talking to a quest giver and then they'd say come see me again and they'd disappear and teleport elsewhere for me to run to. It would have been different if I had done something between, but it felt like just a way for me to walk from one side of the snowy village to the other. For what? So he could quiz me about the clip he just showed me.

There are other small issues I had with the game, like I was running through an area and suddenly it told me my viking is now idle. Click the check mark to reconnect and it never did. It begs the question though, why was I moving and yet still considered idle. There is no Escape menu in this scene and again I had to Alt + F4 out of the game. I couldn't name myself my member name. It said there were numbers in there. I couldn't name my Dragon Gertrude"

reviewText: This is very probably one of the best games ever to grace this world. Over the 20+ years of experience I've had with gaming, I have played various titles such as Big Rigs Over The Road Racing and ET for the Atari 2600, and I must admit this is an almost better experience than those two!\nThe graphics are amazing for a game originally meant to be played on a TI-83 calculator and the sound effects remind me of the good old days of the Atari 5200.\nSome may say that the lip syncing is awful, but I disagree. This is clearly intentional. The developers were trying to pass the message that the words that come out of your mouth aren't always what your heart wanted you to say. Another example of a philosophical message passed by this game is the apparent censorship of every word you try to type in the chat, by claiming they are too offensive". Some people may say this is due to bad coding

reviewText:
This game got my interest because it has dragons. Although you really can ride a dragon, I don't recommend this game (yet).
Also I get the feeling this game is for kids aged around 8. The game is about 1.2 GB in size.
Future updates could improve this game, and this might very well be the reason why the game is free and you have to buy additional stuff to unlock the full game. This is a nice catch to get more people interested in the game.
+ great music
+ you can ride Toothless first time in the game
+ you can ride dragons
+ game is free
+ game is MMO (but can be turned off to speed up the game)
+ if the game is stuck, there is a chance to close the game with ALT+F4
+ game starts quickly

- there are only 4 dragons to choose from (or pay money to get more choices)
- you cannot choose a nightfury dragon to bond with (there's only one nightfury, and that's Toothless)
- you can ride Toothless only for practice (which is in a pretty boring level)
- extra events cost money
- creating more vikings cost money
- bonding with more dragons cost money
- in game videos are bad quality
- controls cannot be changed (instead of strafe you get turn left/right)
- cannot change resolution (game will probably choose resolution for you)
- you have to create an account on an external server
- you cannot play this game offline
-- game crashes a lot. Once so badly I had to repair Windows using a recovery cd.

reviewText:
This game is very much like most MMORPGs: The base game is free and playable, but expansions, some accessories, exotic dragons and mini-game add-ons require gems (the game's purchasable currency)

A lot of reviews complain about the loading times, but in my experience the game loads and runs smoothly. (I have a GTX 650 Ti graphics card and run on Windows 10)

You raise a dragon from baby -> teen -> adult. My hideous zippleback reached adulthood at level 11 after the second day of playing.

You can also have multiple dragons, though extra stable slots will require gems. Gems can be earned by sending emails to friends to join, and after a few days of consecutive log-ins you'll get some prizes and gems as a thanks for your loyalty. Apparently there were campfires where you could sit around and play a very slow game of gem farming" but it was disabled in later updates.

There are mini games where you can earn gold and experience for you and your dragon: Fishing (requires gold to buy bait
date:
though I think you can get worms from compost)

A matching elements game (think bejeweled with the periodic table)

Dragon racing (your dragon needs to be an adult to participate

where you ride your dragon through an assault course and shoot targets to score points

reviewText:
You know, I wouldn't even care that it was Pay to Play, honestly, because I love How to Train Your Dragon so much that I would pay to play in that world. If it was well crafted.

But uh...nope. This was so bad that I, even with my love for all things to do with dragons, gave up on it in no time. FIrst of all, there does not appear to be any way to register over the age of five. According to the devs there supposedly is, but I sure as heck didn't see it and I poked around a fair bit.

The Viking customization is about a third of a step away from nonexisitent, with only two choices for things like hair and outfits. Worse, none of my customization saved. The save for it apparently ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• itself and died at that very second, so I ended up with generic start Viking girl with no name. And I could find no way to change that, either.

The flying is absolute crap. I mean, the first thing you get to do is get on Toothless with Hiccup and seriously, Toothless, you guys. Only...I could even tell, unless I aimed downwards, that the damn dragon was even moving. One of the best parts of HtTYD is how dynamic the flight is, and in this game it is utterly awful.

About the only positive moment was hatching my dragon and watching it follow me around as a precious little baby, but that wasn't enough to keep me wanting to play. I just wasn't interested in a dragon game with craptastic flying. Who would be?

It makes me feel really bad for young gamers, honestly. It's like developers think that kids don't deserve to have good-looking, well-made games. Stop feeding baby gamers shovelware, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s.

reviewText:
The first time I heard about this game was from the CIA Interrogation Report.

As a leader of a team of 360 noscopers, I needed to find a game for my team to play to improve their noscoping potential.  After finding this game, I knew it was the one.


The amount of fun you experience by running from one npc to another ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing npc which are WAY TO ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING FAR AWAY, then just running back to the SAME DAMN NPC is amazing fun.


Another great componant is the level of education and learning you recieve from this game.  This game makes the American Education system look like a complete joke and is obviously made by the Sweds.


The graphics in this game reminds me of my childhood, when I used to play Doom by myself and jack off into my stretch-arm-strong doll.

10/10 would recommend

reviewText: My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. date: I have never touched a cigarette. I must say
recommended: I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it
hoursPlayed: because this game gave me cancer anyway."

reviewText:
This is basicly Wizard 101 but worse and different theme.
I enjoyed both movies and I loved playing wizard 101. So I though the game would be great, I found out it wasn't. I haven't gone far because the 'train your dragon proccess' was boring and half way through my 'dragon fly training' I quit and moved on to be even more bored.
The flying is quite easy once you get used to it but at first it's hard to master. The only dragons you can fly for free is your dragon (once it grows up) or two other Dragon Master dragons.  The flying procedures are basiclly mini-games. There is fishing but I always find fighing really boring in games.
There was really no effort in the bachground when it comes to flying and it was ashame.
And then the game bombardes you with pop-ups with pay for stuff. And I don't dout that very quickly you'll end having to pay to continue playing this game. Not worth the time. Not worth the money they'll require you to spend even though it's a 'Free to play game'.

reviewText:
for a game that just came out all the possible playernames sure have been taken quickly..
spend 90% of my time trying to come up with a name that didn't involve numbers.
the game looks realy unpolished, the person who took those screenshots must have been able to change his settings to ultra, unfortunately I can't find anywhere in game where to do so myself. you get a quick flying tutorial.. (it's funny how forward translates into going up and the spacebar (jump) translates into going forward....) and when you finally get to pick your own dragon... you'll keep running into the  you need to be a (paying) member for this

Pro's :
- very familiar franchise (HTTYD)

Cons:
- need to fully activate your account to find out the name you want to use is allready taken (and the following 200 names you try after that are taken too)
- cost of premium currency to delete your character
- limited customisation for character creation
- terrible graphics (and unable to chance the settings)
- weird controls ( pressing forward make the dragon go up pressing jump makes the dragon go forward. clearly a bad port from a mobile game)
- Freemium written all over the game


I know I only played this game for 20 minutes or so but even then .. I can't honoustly believe dreamworks knows of this games or even approves of it, unless they're willing to sacrifice they're good name for a quick buck...

reviewText:
Through the winds of my low-poly hair, I stood. I contemplated. The world in my grasp. My brothers in combat joined me in the thrilling mountain climbing adventure. Words were unable to describe the beauty of constantly glitching on top of a mountain and surveying the world below. As human beings, we can be pulled into an endless serie of bland adventures. What I felt during this journey belonged to me and me only. The same is with my brothers. Sometimes, you have to teach more than skills. This has taught me what to pass on. Love, poetry, sadness, courage, and compassion. This is what I will pass on. Human beings may not be forever, so we have to leave behind whatever we can to show how far we've come, no matter how grueling our history was. Keeping the past alive and creating the future are part of the same thing.

2/10
-it was ok

reviewText:
This game is amazing! The graphics are A+ - I think the developers went all in when they decided to use JPEGs for their textures! The vomit-inducing camera was an extra bonus! I LOVE to play games and puke profusely onto my keyboard! Oh and I really loved that they chose a blocky look for everything, they must have been influenced by Minecraft or something! The low poly count was fabulous!! Another great thing was that it was just a tablet/mobile port!! I know developers are busy and don't have time to make a PC equivalent - but that's okay because this game is AMAZING!!! It is GREAT having to use mobile and tablet controls on a PC and to have the HUD look like I'm playing on a giant tablet!! GREAT!

The one thing I hated was the music - did they steal that from the movie? I'm disappointed!!
10/10 100/100 BEST GAME BEST GAME" - IGN"

reviewText:
I figured all the other reviews are enough to make you stay away but I actually found it necessary to add my opinion on just how awful this game is.

Customization was awful, you have the options to change your eye color, hair color and skin color. Any other options require a membership (oh wait, you can choose between two tops and two bottoms. Cool.) I soldiered through anyway and got into the actual game.

Right off the bat the voice acting bugged me, I don't know if they had the characters do new voices for this or just took words from the movie and clipped them all together. They sound so vaguely uninterested I was almost ready to exit there. After accepting the first mission I realized the controls aren't the same as most mmos which threw me off because WASD/arrow keys to move is stupid and laggy. I'm guessing it's because it started on mobile (?) but if you're gonna release it for PC at least make some needed changes.

Flying was boring. It said you could hold a button to go faster and all it really did was make you crawl at a slightly quicker pace as though if the game excited you too much you may have a seizure or something. Then you take a personality test and get to choose a dragon which I didn't even bother with because pretty much all the dragons looked stupid bar two and one of them you need a bloody membership for?

Pretty much anything that may pique your interest about this game requires you to buy a membership, as though you'd even waste the money. The best part is I had to restart my viking because I hadn't entered a name and being generic viking #72149657 annoyed me to hell and back, so when I did the flight mission again at the beginning it actually bugged out and toothless floated to the bottom of the screen with no way to get back up and that's about the time I exited the game and decided to write out this review, because writing this 4/5 paragraph long review held more ennjoyment then attempting to play this mmo, don't even waste the space.

reviewText:
Okay, A long time ago I played this game. Being an easily amused and patient child I enjoyed it, but when I came back to it, I realized how stupid it really is.

First of all, I like to be able to customize my character. A lot. In this game it has a  very limited amount of customization, and with the amout of money I had in the game I could only afford one mask. Bullcrap.

The second thing I dislike about this is farming. I hate farming. In many other games I love farming, but here I just hate it. Not because I'm impatient, but because its boring and results in almost no benifit to me. Fishing was okay though. And growing animals. I don't like growing animals in this game.

I don't like how you have to be a member for getting certain dragons. Getting another dragon maybe, but limited starting choices bugs me.

I have a great computer, and it still takes 30 minutes to load. I am pretty sure it should be called The Screen of Tediousness" Loading screen is just too much of a title to live up to.

Not to mention the chat rules. There are several words that I couldn't say

reviewText: The trailer for this game promises top quality graphics, hours of fun gameplay and what looks like an open world.\nWhat you get is actually a poorly made game with more bugs than I can count. When I hatched my dragon, it appeared inside my character, leaving nothing on the dratically revealed pedistal. The actual flight gameplay is as basic and overly structured as it could get. There's no room for wandering off on the back of your new airborne friend. I hot an invisible wall in 5 seconds flat. To unlock more things to do in the game, you have to get out your wallet. If your kids want this, my advice to you is to teach them to have better taste and higher standards of gaming. This is not a 'free' game. If your kids like dragons, go get them Spyro. Spyro's kick-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, and the graphics are actually BETTER THAN THIS.

reviewText:
Gems cost real money to buy, this game is set up to make it way to easy to accidentally spend gems, a lot of the early tutorial missions are coaching you to spend gems. The later missions seem doable but part way through them you find you need something like an advanced fishing road to complete it but guess what it costs you gems.  The only other way to get gems seems now to be to invite friends to join. (and that isn't going to get the many thousands you'll need at 50ges a registration) Add to that it's very glitchy and can crash 3-4 times in a hour. Pay Premium players get everything 80% cheaper so can make more profit in coins but still have to pay gems for anything useful. Coins are useful for buying only bait which you use to catch fish to feed your dragons who get's super hungry doing missions.
Growing crops means you have to buy seed with coins (can't save seed) , water (which runs out fast unless you spend gems on an instafill), carefully not click the spend gems button (to instaharvest) wait up to an hour then click the harvest before the timer expires and the crops are wasted. After spending 200 coins and wasting an hour you might make 40 coins profit, enough to have 4 goes at fishing, which will be wasted if a salmon or an eel takes your bait as you haven't spent gemson the rod capable of catching them or dragons not eating eels. Complaints seem to get the thanks for your copncern, we're making changes treatment but the feeling I get from the forums is things get worse rather than better.
Clans seem a way to peer pressure you to spend  gems to beat other clans.
TLDR don't bother unless you're prepared for a large constant daily cash drain for a glitchy game.

reviewText:
This game has quite a few irksome issues. The flying controls are incredibly weird and you aren't able to reassign them (you can't invert vertical controls to be similar to what you'd find in say arma or battlefield where up arrow means flaps up nose down and vice versa, and you accelerate/decelerate/attack by clicking buttons on the side of the screen?? These buttons are unable to be bound to regular keys). The game takes a long time to load, and also loads in situations that make no sense (i.e. I talked to Hiccup and now I have to load for a solid minute). Graphics settings would be nice, instead of just huge polygons everywhere. It's not my PC causing issues, it should be more than capable of running this game considering I can run much more demanding games on Medium-High graphics settings.

reviewText:
RuneScape is a fantasy massively multiplayer online role-playing game (MMORPG) released in January 2001 by Andrew and Paul Gower, and developed and published by Jagex Games Studio. It is a graphical browser game implemented on the client-side in Java or HTML5, and incorporates 3D rendering. The game has had over 200 million accounts created and is recognised by the Guinness World Records as the world's largest free MMORPG and the most-updated game.

RuneScape takes place in the world of Gielinor, a medieval fantasy realm divided into different kingdoms, regions, and cities. Players can travel throughout Gielinor via a number of methods including on foot, magical spells, or charter ships.Each region offers different types of monsters, resources, and quests to challenge players. The game's fictional universe has also been explored through a tie-in video game on another of its maker's websites, FunOrb, Armies of Gielinor,and the novels Betrayal at Falador,Return to Canifis, and Legacy of Blood.

Players are represented in the game with customisable avatars. RuneScape does not follow a linear storyline; rather, players set their own goals and objectives. Players can choose to fight non-player character (NPC) monsters, complete quests, or increase their experience in the available skills. Players interact with each other through trading, chatting, or by participating in mini-games and activities, some of which are competitive or combative in nature, while others require cooperative or collaborative play.

The first public version of RuneScape was released on 4 January 2001 in beta form, and in December 2001, Jagex was formed to manage the game. As the game's popularity grew, the game engine was rewritten, and its beta was opened to paying players on 1 December 2003 under the name RuneScape 2"
date: and officially released on 29 March 2004.The third iteration of the game

reviewText:
A nice idea for a concept - Really bad attention to gameplay, physics, artifical intelligence and sound.

Gameplay and Physics:
This was a game I was looking forward to try out. At first it seemed promising, but alas, the cover of a book can fool you.
Heads-up devices look terrible and feel unstable. The camera acts really weird - especially when flying.
The physics in the game seem like they have been written by a middle-schooler. Turning angles are awkward and control with mouse and keyboard are confusing (I never thought I'd say that) .  Flying is obviously a big thing in the game, but the physics are impossible! Dragons can stand perfectly still in the sky and the rules of aerodynamics don't apply to them. This removes all immersion for me. If, however, you don't care about the feel of speed and good physics, you will still be disappointed. Going out to explore when having a dragon raised to rank 10, ready to fly, you will find that the scenery is only half done and invisible walls will kep you from going too far anywhere. It has been long since an anti-climax hit me so hard.
In addition to this - there is nothing called damage or crashes. You cannot crash with your dragon or inflict damage to anyone or anything - even though you are given weapons, tools and a fire-breathing dragon.

AI:
The game starts off by introducing you to your dragon. As a guide - you go through a test that then points you to a suggested species of dragon. As for me - I got a dragon that wanted to go around to explore as much as I and play games. This all sounds jolly. To my surprise - it seemed like something fantastic had been done here. But no. The dragons to NOTHING apart from follow you around as a mindless chihuahua in a way too loose leash. No personality, no unexpected features. just empty animations.

Sound:
Oh my God. I don't know where to begin. Absolutely horrible. Simple sounds like your own footsteps (not to mention a 600 kilogram dragon ) are applied to enhance the immersion into the game. I will leave it at that: The sound effects are horrible or absent.
The background music is actually nice. It has a good tune and a realistic feel. Also - it changes with every scene. Good work there.

Graphics:
One thing that makes the game playable is the graphics. They are not high definition, but that is not important. They are funny to look at, without getting too messy - and all in all - it makes the game cosy.
-   Animations, 3D models and Frame hierarchies-
The animations are well made, precise and important. They lift the game to a somewhat acceptable standard (for a free game ) .  The models are authentic to the movies - which is fantastic. Thank you for that, developers. The interaction between the animations and models seem to have been made on a very well build frame hierarchy structure - which is standard in all animated games today. but still - good job.


Samples I liked:
+   I liked that you had to walk around everywhere until your dragon was mature enough to fly. This made the sensation of flying an achievement (until I ragequit because of absurd physics ).

+  I liked the vioce-acting. Very soothing and authentic.

+  I liked all the minigames : fishing, playing eel-catch with dragon and testing things in the lab.



Verdict:

I cannot recommend spending any money on this software. The game world is not big enough and is unfinished, the gameplay seem like it should be much more friendly towards players ( This makes the game feel more like a slot-machine than anything else ) . Games should be made because We - or all developers - have some urge to tell a story or make other people experience something. Not to pump money out of them. (To me this is nothing more than Farmville on facebook)

The level of intelligence in this game could satisfy the mind of a six or eight year old. However - I would not recommend it, because the quest log is non-descriptive and the quest-arrow is buggy - meaning it will sometimes take a LONG time to figure out where to go. The eight year old would have lost his/her patience before rank 10.




The only reason to play this game is to experience the concept - the idea of raising a dragon and then flying it. (If you managed to come as far as to flying your dragon - you have done well.

reviewText:
This game is trash. Here's some of my reasons why:
The graphics look like a game for the PS2
the character controls like a tank a la Resident Evil
The voice acting is either stolen from the show/movies, or done with people who don't even sound like the original characters and sometimes even sound unintentionally sarcastic when they're talking to you.
It also has microtransactions. (also known as In-App Purchases)I fail to see how ANYONE would want to pay for something as broken, boring or so low quality as this.
Garbage.
Utter garbage. Especially for 2014.

Credit to Lance for things and stuff.
TL;DR Do NOT play this.

reviewText:
To play this game I advise you to use a good computer/device to run it, otherwise you will encounter lag and common crashes.

Personally I think this game is very good, I really reccomend it to all How to Train Your Dragon fans! There are a lot of people who do not like it because of the bugs in it, but if you have good internet and network this should reduce those issues by far! The Admins in this game are constantly updating it, adding new expansion packs ( e.g Icestorm Island), releasing new dragon eggs, new items/clothing ect. The possabilties in this game are pretty much endless! You can go on to the official site and check the forums for the latest updates and news! There is loads of activities to do like Thunder Run Racing, Fire Ball Frenzy, Bulls Eye Lagoon ect. along with all the quests you are given through out your adventure to becoming an Ultimate Dragon Trainer!

The only thing I really dislike about this game is its glitches, connection issues and the occasional moment where the server times out. These can be resolved by a simple restart. If these issues are common for you, this may be from your internet or the strenght of your device you are chosing to play it from.

I hope you do have a great gaming expirience in this game and I hope this review was helpful!

:D

reviewText:
Not as bad as people say it is.

Don't let my playtime fool you, I've played this extensively in-browser before getting a computer that wasn't a brick with 2GB of RAM.

The game can be fun- it's obviously a game directed at children, what with its random science and way of speaking- and the microtransactions are easy enough to ignore. Aside from non-starter dragon eggs and certain Shop things, everything you can get with Gems is also obtainable just by being patient ingame. It's not the game's fault if you don't want to put the work in to level up your dragon and get flying that way.

Crashes rarely happen on a halfway decent system. I had one crash" which was really just caused by my computer acting up as I was alt-tabbing out to my browser to look up one of the dragons and had to close the game manually.

The game doesn't shove its microtransactions in your face unless you click on something that requires it
date: such as an activity when your active dragon is too young or an expansion you don't have.\n\nActually
recommended: when I was playing brower-based I remembered it was incredibly easy to cheese he referral-for-gems system
hoursPlayed: since it didn't track your IP. My friend got a Skrill egg just by making a few fake accounts."

reviewText:
A neat Idea, poor execution. School of Dragons is playable, and you may enjoy it if you are a fan of the series, and can stand the looks. The game is not pretty but I havent noticed anything specifically terrible about the game. its basic, but it can still be enjoyable.

Notes:

1. You will probobly be accosted with adds wanting you to become a member, and or pay gems for extra stuff. there are a lot of these adds, you have been warned.

2. You might as well not even try to chat. if you do be very careful of what you say and how you say it. I haven't had any trouble as of yet. But I have seen people complaining of bans for using basic non cursewords and such. Again this is not first hand experience on my part but the game is clearly designed for children who have parents with deep pockets. Try to keep your chat super clean, or else you'll get a banhammer.

reviewText:
[Dead Honest Review]

So I think I've enough time in this game to thoroughly review this game. Let me start off with the Pros

Pros
-------
+Amazing graphics (MUCH better than the Witcher 3, just in case you need a comparison)
+Story rich!
+The quests are VERY well done, and are NEVER the same, not even the side quests!
+Voice acting is amazing, literally THE best
+Character design is spot-on
+Massive open world game, FILLED with amazing quests, characters and other players!
+Dragons!
+Amazing character creation!

Now on to the cons...

Cons
-------
-The graphics are sort of demanding, I can sometimes run it at like 30 fps

This is seriously the best game I've ever played, seriously blowing games like The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt completely out of the playing field. DOWNLOAD THIS GAME!


In all seriousness, why is this on steam, isn't this a freaking mobile phone game or something?

reviewText:
First lets just drop any reviews under 1 hour because their Loading screen issues are the actual files updating like any other MMO and thats why the loading screen takes time the first time you load. They did not play and have no real perception of the game play. Yes the intial load takes time just let the files update. NOW FOR THE GAME REVIEW!

Pros:
- Meant for kids obviously given the game type. My 4 year old can play it and has for a period of time the reading is what stumps him at times because some things do but its a game reading is required.

-The games in the game are easy to play  which allows interaction with your dragon.

- Educational ( good for kids in this instance) Example: One of the first quests is an Experiment which can take your child through all the steps required to do their own experiment  Problem, Hypothesis ect. Addtionally some of the games have your win screen with interactions that give interesting facts. Facts at the age of 26 I did not know probably because I'm not a Marine biologist but all the same good information to help your kids just know a little more.

- Graphically for the engine they are using not too bad for a F2P MMO

- Key binds are super simple does not require hot keys so it is primarily just click based interactions making it a very simple game.

- Energy bar for your dragon Feed them Fish easy fix


Cons-

- Lots of load screens between areas that is a bit of a pain I would say atleast 1 hour of game play will get you about 5 to 10 minutes of load screens between areas but not all in one spot its broken up in to about 30 second load screens while questing.



- A lot of the gear requires gems gems require money so for that it can be kind of frustrating because who doesn't like to get new gear in an MMO, but there is other currency for item purchases in the game.

- Too much clicking at times to proceed a lot is double checking for you to leave a current interaction.  Are you sure you want to leave?" " Are you sure your sure you want to leave?" kind of redundant in a way but deal able because load screens can follow some of the interactions and you end up wasting more time by loading when you had the second opportunity to stop.


Remember Every game has its pro's and Cons but we can not base a game off " Mixed reviews" when half the people fail to even let the game update after the inital download. If you can deal with a WOW patch you can take the 15 mins to let the files update on the game this reduces your initial load time every time you go in to the game and it is heavily reduced. Hope this helps overall not a bad game especially for a kid."

reviewText:
I had an account on SoD before downloading the Steam version. The online version would never load for me but this one went into the game almost instantly and plays well.

The game is probably best suited for ages around 12-14 but I still think it's fun despite the absolutely ridiculous word filter which doesn't let you use words including 'Droggle' 'Banana' 'Baby' 'Brun' and 'Sword'.
Like most MMO's, there are a lot of pay features, most of the dragons are sub only but you still get four customisable types to choose from for free: Gronkles, Hideous Zipplebacks, Deadly Nadders and Monsterous Nightmares.
For dragons such as Whispering Death, Scauldron, Stormcutter, Rainutter, Screaming Death, Nightfury, etc. you're going to have to pay. The game is still perfectly playable and enjoyable without the pay features, they just make things a lot easier.

The world is still fairly small at this point but there seems to be areas where the world will be developed further, paths leading to boarded up tunnels and locked doors, that sort of thing. Hoping to see more developments soon.

There are a few bugs and glitches in the game. I've only experienced a minor one which doesn't set me back at all. Just be aware that certain elements may cause your game to crash and you may find certain quests unachievable. The developers encourage players to report any issues to them.

reviewText: School of Dragons is a massively multiplayer online roleplaying game set in the universe of the 2010 critically-acclaimed Dreamworks Animations film, How to Train Your Dragon, and its sequel. Step into the life of a Viking dragon rider and journey beyond the Isle of Berk to the mainland continent and the surrounding islands, home to dozens of exotic dragons. Train your dragon from birth, join clans and unite with your fellow dragon trainers, ride on the backs of these majestic winged beasts, and relive the thrill of How to Train Your Dragon in stunning graphical detail -- free to play!

Cons: Very loongg loading screens,  Keyboard controls are fixed in place, and can be Pay to Win.  Might work better using website.
Try it if you like the movies and you have children.

reviewText:
Good game. Features many of the things that made the movies a hit.
Only 2 problems for me:
1. Game won't open properly in fullscreen. Instead, opens into a squashed view.
2. Freezes every 5 minutes. I have to restart my computer to continue.
Otherwise, great game! Looking forward to seeing these issues fixed, and playing more!

reviewText:
For working with a universe like HtTYD, this isn't too bad. Sure, there is no real combat system, the level progression seems a bit awkward, and I dont understand the purpose of a health bar when there is no way to even get hurt (literally walked off of a cliff and landed perfectly fine). Not to mention the lack of direction and no main story to keep you engaged. Or at the very least make the characters more interesting.
However, you have to remember that there is really nothing that you'd be able to fight. Maybe Outcasts or Berserkers, but that would be about it without ruining the essence of HtTYD. But it would still be nice if there was something to make the game at least a little more interesting.

That being said, if you just wanted to rp having your own dragon and being apart of said universe, I say go for it. The graphics are not that bad all things considered. Most of the characters re-appear, alond with their dragons. So you can go ahead and rp as a member of the HH tribe, or who ever you want to be. Sure the game may glitch here and there, and the enviornment may be a little lacking, but it works. The dragon flight controls take a little getting used to, but after that, they're not too bad. The Pay-to-win" features can get a little annoying some times but they are not down right agrivating. The loading screens can be a bit frustrating at times but you can ignore them
date: I tend to just read the little comments above the loading bar.\n\nI honestly believe that while lacking
recommended: this game isnt nearly as bad as most people give it credit for. Most have only played for an hour or less
hoursPlayed: not really giving it a fair assessment. I believe that the game is still in the works and that it will improve
voteText: so we just have to be patient with it.\n\nSo I would recommend this game for anyone who fevently loves HtTYD

reviewText: It's a pretty fun game, but the saying for games like these stands true to form. Free to Play, but Pay to Win. If you want the best Dragon, you have to pay the most money along with having a membership. But all in all, it's possible to play this game without spending any money (which is what I did) and I'm enjoying it. There are a few instances of some...weird gameplay chat, but it's not really common as it's a shared chat. That deters a good deal of the roleplayers from their...roleplaying haha. I like it, and it's one of those games where if you just want to cruise around on a dragon, you can do that, but if you want to get serious and do some quests, you can do that too and make some coins along the way. So yeah, it's a good game and I recommend it.

reviewText: Instead of negative reviews this game has earned here, I have to say at least something positive. I have not played it for long enough yet, but I find it enjoyable and really nice. The graphics are not the best, but still really good and makes me part of the movie+series universe. It is more of a fairy tale game meant for children that even adults can enjoy as they can play it with them. It reminds me of Harry Potter And the Prisoner of Azkaban, when I played Harry flying on a Buckbeak. Sure many things could be made better (for example the constant membership/gem adds throughout the game annoy me) but as a game meant for children to LEARN, yes learn as some of the scientific stuff/mathematics, logics, really helps children to learn and gain some knowledge. Easy to navigate and the BIG icon bars are there also to help children. So just to oppose those negative ANTI-Recommendations - THIS is a game meant for KIDS to play and LEARN but it is also ENJOYABLE for other generations as well.

reviewText:
I personally really like the game. While the game crashes occasionally and some things cost gems (gems costs real money), I do think that game has a few more positives than negatives. The different dragons are cool, the minigames are really fun, the music is awesome, and a lot of quests are fun to do.

I only really have one major issue with it, and it's only when racing. My problem is that most of the race tracks have unintentional shortcuts that can skip entire sections of a track, and many people abuse them! I've made a two personal rules of mine when racing. The first is to not use fireballs (because in my opinion, fireballs in the races are really cheap), and the second one is to never use broken shortcuts. So when nearly everybody that races uses these shortcuts, it really aggrivates myself and others that just want to have a fair race.

Overall I recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the movies, or that wants somthing different.

reviewText: Over all a good game to follow the movies.\nAfter playing both HTTYD" for DS and "Dragons 2" for the 360
date: i must admit that i wasn't expecting too much else different from this game
recommended: but once i made my account and started i was pleasantly suprised by what i found. The game has a very nice combination of mechanics from both titles without really dragging the game down.\n\nThis would include that like the first HTTYD there is the ability to walk around and interact with the environment and characters
hoursPlayed: as well as quests to do that can level up your dragon
voteText: and of course dragon customization!\n\nWhile like Dragons 2 there is the entire flight system! With an open world to fly around in and explore this opens up many other fun things to the player
helpfulPercent: and with this game being massively multiplayer you no longer need your friends to come over to your house to play local splitscreen just to fly around with them. There is also much more than just Berk now
votesHelpful:
you have lots of new maps to explore with Expansion packs for even more to do.


NOTE: IN THE NEW UPDATE 1.19.0 THESE BUGS HAVE BEEN FIXED!
All that said
votesTotal: there is more than a few flaws to this game. Mainly Bugs and Glitches....\nI've noticed several farm and quest glitches where farm jobs appear in your quest book
votesFunny: or where quests become unselectable after a time
commentsCount: meaning the quest arrow WILL NOT help you in that objective again. This happened to all my Expansion quests (since i didnt have the packs i couldn't do the quests) after a time of them being active but unfinished
column16:
if this occurs for anyone else the only solution i know is to actually read the NPC dialoge and follow their instructions...
These are probably the most noticable ones for me but these are not the only ones.


Aside from that the multiplayer chat has a very messed up sensor that not only blocks swears from being used but all the numbers as well as the word for a number
column17: meaning if you want to say to the other people "twenty minutes till the battle"(etc.) you have to write " wenty mins till the battle" or something dumb like that.....\n\nAfter all that (All glitches aside as there should be a bug fix update eventually...) i would call this a good game and rate it about 8/10"

reviewText:
A contender for Game of the Year! For sure!


This game allows for the player to experience a certain dichotomy between the experience of training dragon and the experience of living in the moment. A roller coaster, an up-and-down thrill ride, through and through. This game certaintly gave me the experience that I think I needed to finally put  on par with Bioshock. This game might even top bioshock. Loved the story, but gives that old fashioned MMO feel that any fan of the genre would like.

8/8 M8

reviewText:
Where can I start with this amazing game?

STORY: The story is about an ancient dragon that has returned to earth after thousands of years. He wants to end the world. You, the Dragonborn, has to stop him in his tracks. This is only the main story, though. There's tons of sidequests, and the lore of this universe is extremely deep.

GRAPHICS: The game's graphics are stunning for a 2011 game. Skyrim is a beautiful province, and everything feels different, from the icy peak of High Hrothgar to the forests of the Rift.

GAMEPLAY: The gameplay is great, and dragon fights are epic. There's a lot of different weapons and armour to be found throughout the game, and there's hundreds of locations to discover.

I wish I could replay this with the same sense of awe and discovery as the first time I played it.

Overall, I would say this game is a 10/10.

reviewText:
This game is so revolutionary. The graphics are top notch and don't look like they were made on the Atari 2600.
The gameplay is phenomenal. You can walk up trees and walk sideways on mountains. Clearly this defies all logic in gaming.
It is so fun that you can watch a loading screen for more than 3 hours.
Look at the fantastic movement of the dragons. They take 1 hour to move forward.
Surely the developers knew that we wanted 'Superman 64: PC Edition'
I'm pretty sure that this will win game of the century for its realistic tone and revolutionary loading screens.

The reviews for this game are more interesting than the game itself
4/2 - IGN

reviewText:
As wonderful as the idea of flying around on Berk and rasing your own dragons from an egg may be, it's execution is horrid. In reality, you can hardly walk without having to pay for something.
You pay with either gems or coins, the latter being scarce, the first as rare as night furies.
Adds wait around every corner and pounce at you whenever you try to do something. Even feeding your dragon costs buckets of money, and to even be able to raise another one, you need to buy expensive stables, which are prized more like luxury penthouses.
Dragon eggs can also only be obtained by spending affromentioned gems, wild dragon nests are non-interactable, if you can even find one that is.
To summarize the game in one sentence; BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY BUY!
Everything is so focused on you spending actual, real-life money on it, that it becomes hardly playable. And certainly not a fun pass-time. I Definitely do not reccomend this game to anyone.
And don't even get me started on all the bugs
When it comes to freemium games, I'd prefer candy crush. At least that one is still playable, and even enjoyable, witouth having to spend real-life currency.

reviewText: Hello people who are thinking about playing this game. My name is Sefh and I'm bringing you this exclusive review of School of Dragons. Me and my dragons have awesome adventures and I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes dragons overall. Be sure to subscribe to the game in order to unlock 1 new hairstyle, it is so great I can't take my eyes of it. I am addicted to this game and might require assistance to stop playing it, but nothing will stop me this year -- perhaps in 2015.

reviewText:
After checking the dreadful reviews I couldnt keep my masochistic self away from it, and jumped into this journey that was meant to enlighten my thoughts of the saga, and i gotta say I got stuck on account registration,where i tried to figure out my age, 2 was fair enough.

Then in an attempt to ride Toothless, my character appeared on its back on an empty sky while phasing through him, dropping onto a seemingly endless void, reaching water, and starting to swim at the speed of a submarine with the periscope on the surface.

You aint understanding nothing unless youre a kid or high as hell on dragon nip, would play again 11/10.

reviewText:
Believe it or not, I've actually been enjoying this game.
NOW HEAR ME OUT!
Maybe it's because I love the HTTYD franchise, maybe it's because I love having my own dragon to raise, maybe it's because puberty treated Hiccup well. However, I found the game to be colourful and frankly a breath of fresh air.
The graphics are outdated and similar to PS2 graphics, it's glitchy, and I've lost my dragon several times just walking around. However, this game had many more glitches before I started playing it apparently, considering I was able to input my appropriate age and I only crashed once. What we must keep in mind is this game just came out yesterday. Understandably, who would want to put a glitchy, unfinished product on the market? *cough* Ubisoft *cough* But that's the beauty of MMO's, although sometimes glitchy at first, they develop and grow over time with the right support. I think this game has a lot of potential and I'm willing to stick around for it. The cutscenes are nothing to ogle at and they play scenes from the movies for some of the quests I've done so far. Call me blinded by nostalgia, but throwing movie scenes into a computer game takes me back to the old Disney PC games. Of course, it shows laziness on development's part by not creating these cutscenes themselves, but I can still appreciate putting scenes in from the movie.
tl;dr version: I like this game. While it has it's flaws I think it has potential. 10/10 would have toothless follow my cursor in the lab again.

column17: yes there are options to pay in-game however it is not Pay to Play* and yes it's a child's game.\n**The game offers in-game payment options to be a member. This does not mean it's "Pay to Play" as pay to play simply means to use real currency to continue in the game
column19:
and unlock classes etc that are not available any other way. Paying in-game grants you membership which simply means;
-No Ads (Original Website)
-500 Free Gems Monthly*
-All Flight Club Dragons*
-20% Off InStore
-Hiccups Flightsuit
-Your Own Toothless

**Gems help you buy a lot of stuff in the game however does not generally affect how you get through the game. Gems are used to by costumes
column20: unnecessary gold that can be earned through jobs and quests
column21: farm accessories to make your farm look better than the rest
column23: consumables that really have no use except restoring energy which you can do by fishing. Yes you can by better dragons
column24:
but default dragons can be just as good.

**All Flight Club dragons are not your own personal dragons and may just help you get a better grade in that class. By default you can use your own dragon or Terror. Unlocking them is not a necessity.

Anyone can play just as good as a person who pays."

reviewText:
*sigh* School of Dragons had potential, but failed poorly in execution. The gameplay feels clunky, the quests (which is SUPPOSED to be the main part of any MMORPG) feels empty, unrewarding and mainly consists of fetch-quests. Except from a few minigames, which are rather boring already, there isn't really any content for the game. Unless you are willing to become a member. But even then, you only get new dragons to ride on(which, may sound cool, it's done in a very, very awkward way.) and some new cosmetics. Then nothing else. NOTHING at all. You can finish all the quests in like a week's time(granted, I finished it in like 3 days back when it is still only on their website via Unity Web Player, with all the guide arrows last year, but still they are on by default...) and then you got nothing to do. Riding and raising your own dragons is a cool thing...but they set up payment barriers for F2Ps so that they need to pay in order to get more dragons, which, I'm doubting they would, seeing that they game does not actually have enough content to keep them there.(Or, they could potentially just start a new account to experience it again....I did. And I admit I was dumb.)

But by far, the most disappointing thing about this game, is not how the graphic is terrible, comparing to what Unity could actually do(I feel like that the reason for the horrid graphics is to make sure that a lot more pcs can run it and to maintain the same experience for all players across and probably add in that their servers might not be able to handle massive data flow or something like that, I don't know. It's just speculation. As a sidenote though, AT LEAST LET THE PLAYERS CHOOSE THE RESOULTION OF THE GAME THAT THEY WANT TO PLAY ON), it's the aim of the game and demographic players for the game.

I'm a fan of the How To Train Your Dragons series for a while now, and what I've seen from the online fandom, is that they are mostly consist of people who are teens and even young adults, instead of what the game is targeting at, which is like for 6-10 year-olds. So there's a lot of quests in the game that attempts to teach the players about real-world science that they are supposed to be learning at school, and the entire game felt like it was too dumbed down to cater for them.

First of all, the science quests. They. Ruin. Immersion. NO one wants to learn science in a world where glass is a valuable and people wear horned helmets to protect themselves in the constant battles and dragons are real. In fact, I'm pretty sure that during the Viking age, most of what we learned about since today hasn't even been theorized or ever touched on! I would rather just focus on training dragons and fly with them, thank you very much.

I remember like the original aim was to like 'train, raise your own dragon and learn real world science along the way' or something like that, That's just something I can't agree on.

And then there's the catering problem. I know, How To Train Your Dragon is supposed to be a children's film, but it feels mature(especially in the sequel, I don't want to spoil it so go find yourself and cry forever. A major character's parent died.), that's probably why it gathered a number of older fans, but even then, the game developers ignored the needs of them and would rather create something to milk money for themselves. Shame on you.

If you are a fan of the Dragons franchise, you could go try out the game...on your own behalves. This game is just not worth it. As for anyone else, nope. Don't even get the idea to click that button to install. It's not worth your time.

reviewText: Where to begin. The graphics are crap. There isn't even an option to turn them up or down. It's just permalocked turdvision. Speaking of options, character customization is ABSOLUTE ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. There are like 2 choices of hair and 2 choices of face, both of which look ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• as hell. There are multiple bugs throught the game and they arent major except for the part where the mission you're on spontaneously termiantes and you cant move forward. I was really looking forward to playing in the HTTYD universe and I understand that this is targeted at kids but c'mon. This is 2014, this game plays like it just came out for the Nintendo 64. Did you really release a game like this and expect no one to notice. Not to mension, it takes SO LONG for you to actually ride your beloved dragon. I didn't even get to the point where i can actually ride it but I imagine it would be less like the movies and more like Superman 64 for anyone who remembers that game. This should not be considered a complete game, not even Beta for that matter. This is someone wiping there ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• on a keyboard and somehow managing to write code that produces a barely functional program and deciding to publish his ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•_wipe.exe to steam. Furthermore, you have to PAY to DELETE a character and there is only one character slot. Honestly, wtf. Speaking of pay, microtranactions. Microtransactions everywhere, There is also a paid subscription option which unlocks for you an experience similar to that of eating turd flacored ice cream with sprinkles and caramel. Dont bother with this game.

reviewText:
As you can see, I have played this game a lot. I really like it but I can understand if others can't. There are lots of problems with this game that -I feel- if are fixed this will be a much loved game. For starters;
1. Glitches
Almost everywhere there are glitches, mainly graphic ones though. Everytime I try to complete a certain quest the game freezes and I yet again, have to restart the game.
2. Graphics
A ladder (that is the only way to get to the top of a mountain without a flying age dragon) you cannot climb without getting stuck and having to restart the game. Deep sea fishing, when you get close to the water the sea turns white and starts flashing as well as the rock you sit on out there is highlight pink. It always ignores the fact that wings are not like ghosts and should not go through rock. The trees are in 2D...?
3. So Expensive!
Anything that has to be bought is expensive, even as a member with a discount. The dragons I understand, but things like 70 Gems for a new hairstyle? 8 gold per piece of bait? 48 gold for 1 seed of carrots? Animals! Food for animals/Dragons!
4. Dragons
There is only One Skrill In the show as well as one Night Fury So why can I buy a Skrill and paint it whatever colour I want but only one Night Fury- Toothless (whose colour cannot be changed and can only be obtained through being a member).
Also, More dragons should be made into the game because I want more for my growing collection. I would also like to be able to sell my dragons incase of double-ups because I'm sure you get a Whispering Death for completing a certain mission. I already have one and do not wish to go through all my missions to level up a dragon I alrweady have.
4. Missions
I feel there is not enough missions. I have often run out of them on both profiles, there is one that you are always able to do but you get 5 gold, 5 XP, 5 Dragon XP and 5 UDT points for it for 30 minutes of stuff. There is also a mission that cannot be completed on both profiles due to a glitch where it freezes when you are about to make a step to complete it. Leaving me with only one possible mission that is a complete waste of time.
5. Education...? RUFKM?
If I wanted to see the words Hypothisis, Scientific Method, Convex, Concave, Botanist, Chemical Reaction, Science Experiment, Refract or Prisim I would be playing a Breaking Bad, Big Bang Theory, Science Class cross over game. I get that it is driven for kids but no matter how many times you say most of these the average kid is going to be like WTF? I want to get back to the Dragons!". It makes me feel lame when those words come up because I remember that my actual nerd friends are playing WoW and LoL and I am in fact playing a kids game.

With all these issues I still love this game and still recommend it. I can fly a dragon! I'm going to be honest and say that I have no idea why I like this game. But I do
date: I've told you all these problems to give you a clear image of the game and although I can't particually give you reasons to play it apart from "FUN" and "DRAGONS" I ask you give it a go and get your own opinion of this game that I set Anime aside for."

reviewText: It was a quiet monday morning. Sunlight broke through my window covers and shone on my face. I awoke. It was a beautiful day. The birds were chirping their merry songs and I saw the neighbors exchanging friendly conversation. I turned on my computer and got online. My friend, Kyle, messaged me. We got caught up on our lives. He mentioned a new game that he found. A unique one based on the popular How to Train your Dragon Series. Feeling adventurous, we both downloaded it and began to play. Immediately, a smilie appeared on my face. I couldn't help. I just new from the very beginning that this game was something truly magically. The music perfectly set the mood. I began to feel like a viking myself. When I began creating my character, the amount of choices overwhelmed me. I created a character that fit my persona and felt truly connected. Then cutscenes introed the game and oh god the cutscenes. So masterfully crafted you would think they got them straight out a movie. When I finally began playing, everything fit in place. It was perfect. The controls were simple and fun. The interface was easy and clear. Voice acting was top notch. I think they got the actual movie actors! Everything was fun. Please, do yourself a favor and play this game.\n1/10 IGN- Game of the Year

reviewText: It was a quiet monday morning. Sunlight broke through my window covers and shone on my face. I awoke. It was a beautiful day. The birds were chirping their merry songs and I saw the neighbors exchanging friendly conversation. I turned on my computer and got online. My friend, Kyle, messaged me. We got caught up on our lives. He mentioned a new game that he found. A unique one based on the popular How to Train your Dragon Series. Feeling adventurous, we both downloaded it and began to play. Immediately, a smilie appeared on my face. I couldn't help. I just new from the very beginning that this game was something truly magically. The music perfectly set the mood. I began to feel like a viking myself. When I began creating my character, the amount of choices overwhelmed me. I created a character that fit my persona and felt truly connected. Then cutscenes introed the game and oh god the cutscenes. So masterfully crafted you would think they got them straight out a movie. When I finally began playing, everything fit in place. It was perfect. The controls were simple and fun. The interface was easy and clear. Voice acting was top notch. I think they got the actual movie actors! Everything was fun. Please, do yourself a favor and play this game.\n1/10 IGN- Game of the Year
